AFTER EVERYTHING $MSFT INVESTED -- OPENAI MOVES INFERENCE TO $GOOGL TPUS

This tells you two things:

1. Compute is constrained. Margins are tightening. Even the most advanced lab in the world needs cheaper, scalable inference -- and Googleâ€™s TPU stack delivers it.

2. This isnâ€™t just a chip play. Google controls the model (Gemini), the hardware (TPUs) & the interface (Search, Gmail, YouTube, Android). Thatâ€™s MASSIVE leverage.

Inference is where the money is.
Training is occasional. Inference is constant.

This isnâ€™t just a win for TPUs.
Itâ€™s a validation of Googleâ€™s full-stack flywheel -- and Googleâ€™s loop is already live.

EVERYONEâ€™S OBSESSED WITH THE CARS AND THE GAS -- BUT NO ONEâ€™S LOOKING AT THE ROAD

Iâ€™ve been getting approached a lot lately at social events with questions about AI -- where itâ€™s going, what to watch, what matters.

Hereâ€™s how I break it down:

â€¢ Training data is the gas -- $NVDA, $AVGO, $AMD, $ASML, $TSM, $ARM, $ALAB, $MRVL, $AMZN, $MSFT, $GOOGL, $NBIS, $CRWV

â€¢ AI applications are the cars -- $SNOW, $PLTR, $TSLA, $CRWD, $MDB, $NOW, $PANW, $NET, $RBRK

â€¢ The energy grid is the highway -- $OKLO, $VRT, $EOSE, $BWXT, $SMR, $CEG, $NNE, $CCJ, $LEU, $VST

And hereâ€™s what no oneâ€™s pricing in: gas is getting cheaper. Fast. 

Training costs are collapsing. Itâ€™s about to become insanely cheap to go from Point A (raw data) to Point B (real-world output).

That means one thing: a surge of new AI â€œcarsâ€ hits the road -- apps, agents, copilots -- all moving data to decisions at scale. Everyoneâ€™s hitting the road at once.

But hereâ€™s the problem -- the highway isnâ€™t ready.
Grid capacity. Cooling. Storage. Baseload. Itâ€™s not there yet.

Thatâ€™s the real bottleneck.

Forget the chips and the models for a second -- if the infrastructure breaks, everything breaks.

Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m laser-focused on the grid layer. Because once the road opens up, everything else flies.
